Ternary nanostructured materials, fabricated by integrating three diverse metals, have been considered as promising cathode catalysts for fuel cells because of their synergetic effects and strain/ligand effects. That can result in effective charge transfer, weakened interactions with oxygenated species, and excellent methanol resistance. Owing to continued improvements in the production of ternary nanostructured materials, it is imperative to focus on recent advancements in this field. The present paper reviews different ternary nanostructures (i.e., support-free structures and supported catalysts), with an emphasis on their preparation methods, compositional and structural characteristics, as well as catalytic performance for oxygen reduction reactions (ORR). Moreover, the latest advances in ternary nanostructured catalysts for ORR at the cathodes of proton exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs) and direct methanol fuel cells (DMFCs) are highlighted. This work provides insights into designing advanced ternary catalysts with an analysis of challenging issues in developing highly efficient and stable nanomaterials for ORR electro-catalysis and suggests some perspectives for alleviating the difficulties toward practical implementation. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Ternary nanostructured materials Cathode catalysts Fuel cells Oxygen reduction reaction Electro-catalysis Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Fuel cell technologies have emerged as green and effective alternative power sources, which can significantly reduce dependency on traditional and non-environment friendly fossil fuel-based energy [1,2]. Polymer exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs) have aroused tremendous attention owing to their efficiency in converting chemical energy stored in hydrogen (H2) into electricity through electro-chemical reactions [3–5]. Although H2 is an efficient and eco-friendly fuel, difficulties related to its sourcing, transportation, and storage impede its utilization [6,7]. The direct methanol fuel cell (DMFC), which consumes methanol as a fuel, is another electro-chemical device that has the potential to produce clean energy [8,9]. Due to their convenience in terms of transportation and storage, high volumetric energy density, and generation using renewable biomass sources or natural gas, liquid-methanol fuels are preferable to gaseous H2 [7,10–12]. Nonetheless, DMFCs have inferior efficacy for a variety of reasons, including sluggish oxygen reduction and methanol oxidation processes, as well as methanol migration from the anode to the cathode compartment through the membrane (cross-over of methanol) [13–16]. Platinum (Pt) nanoparticles deposited on carbon are usually adopted as catalysts for the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) in fuel cell systems, but limited availability, poor methanol tolerance, insufficient stability, and the unaffordable price of Pt make fuel cell technologies extremely expensive for widespread commercialization [17–20]. To address this matter, considerable efforts have been made to replace or reduce the loading of Pt. As a result, some multicomponent catalysts with improved ORR catalytic properties have been developed for fuel cell applications [9,21,22]. It is of utmost importance to design more stable and less costly innovative multimetallic catalysts with favorable oxygen reduction catalytic capability. Trimetallic nanocatalysts, which are composed of three diverse metals with distinctive morphological features, are of keen interest in this regard. Trimetallic alloyed nanomaterials exhibit improved ORR catalytic performance, exceeding that of other reported nanocatalysts due to a wide range of fascinating properties in the ternary systems [23,24]. So, the construction of ternary nanostructured catalysts with earth-abundant metallic elements has been a key topic in ORR catalysis research. In general, trimetallic nanocatalysts comprise nanoclusters or nanoalloys of three various transition metals in their reduced state. It is expected that systematically constructed trimetallic nanomaterials with well-organized sizes, compositions, surface areas, and morphologies can boost electro-catalytic activity for ORR [25–31]. Because of their adjustable features and markedly enhanced ORR electro-catalytic abilities compared to single and binary nanocatalysts, such ternary structures have attracted a great deal of interest [32,33]. Inspired by their attractive attributes, numerous attempts have been made to devise advanced trimetallic alloyed nanocatalysts with extraordinary structural compositions and arrangements. The use of common preparation techniques has led to a variety of functional nanomaterials with promising ORR efficiency [34,35]. Furthermore, the ability to modify the compositions of trimetallic nanomaterials makes it easier to prevent a general alteration in physio-chemical characteristics thanks to the presence of the third metallic component. The development of ternary nanomaterials for ORR is one of the main strategies to overcome bimetallic catalyst limitations. The synergy between distinct metal elements, high selectivity, electronic and geometric effects, resistance to degradation, and structural flexibility of ternary catalysts attracts the research community to explore more about these materials [34,36,37]. To date, several ternary metal nanocatalysts with various structural and compositional properties have been proposed to promote ORR electro-catalysis in fuel cells [38–41]. Even so, the oxygen reduction performance of ternary nanostructured materials remains insufficient to meet the standards for industrial applications. Consequently, it is highly desirable to thoroughly investigate current advancements in this field. In recent years, few review papers have highlighted the fabrication and potential applications of ternary nanostructures, while the majority of these studies are concentrated on electro-catalytic applications in half-cells [42–51]. However, these reviews did not specifically consider ternary nanocatalysts for oxygen reduction, and a detailed clarification of the impact of third elements on enhancing the ORR electro-catalytic performance of ternary systems in full-cells is lacking. Hence, with the rapid advancements in ternary nanocatalysts, offering a timely and comprehensive update in this field is essential. This motivates us to elaborate on the current review and elucidate the design of ternary nanostructures (i.e., support-free and supported electro-catalysts) for oxygen reduction, as well as their fundamental ORR mechanism. Advances in the development of binary electro-catalysts and their major stability issues are examined to demonstrate the activity-stability advantages of ternary nanostructured materials. Then, the latest progress regarding ternary nanomaterials for oxygen reduction catalysis in half-cells and fuel cells is described (Fig. 1 ). Furthermore, the factors that impact the ORR activity of ternary nanocatalysts (such as reactants, electrolytes, compositions/morphologies, and methanol poisoning) are also discussed. Meanwhile, the challenges related to tricomponent nanomaterials and several perspectives are presented to pave the path toward developing the next generation of efficient and robust ternary catalysts for large-scale applications of fuel cells. 2 Mechanism of oxygen reduction ORR is a common reaction in energy-converting devices [52,53]. Nevertheless, the electro-chemical oxygen reduction path is intricate and includes some elementary stages (chemical process or electron transmission) together with an array of intermediate products [54–56]. In addition, the reduction of oxygen is substantially influenced by the attributes of electro-catalysts, electrode materials, and electrolytes. The generally accepted oxygen reduction routes can be classified into two categories: one is the two-electron reduction through transporting O2 and generating HO2 − in alkaline conditions or H2O2 in acidic conditions, while the other is the four-electron reduction through converting O2 to OH− in alkaline conditions or water in acidic conditions [32,57–60]. Fig. 2 a and b depict the two-electron and four-electron reduction processes in acidic and alkaline solutions. Indeed, the mechanisms of oxygen reduction are more sophisticated than those represented by the equations in Fig. 2a and b, owing to the probability of the mentioned reactions happening simultaneously. Oxygen reduction must occur through the four-electron process to attain maximum energy output [61–63]. Hence, the four-electron reduction route is the most favored mechanism in fuel cell devices. Even though the four-electron process is more efficient, the two-electron reduction process will inevitably coexist [58,59]. The proportion of the two-electron reduction process in the overall ORR procedure may vary, but it will still be present to some extent. The selection of two-electron reduction paths is strongly impacted by the potential for dissociation of OO bonding on the surface of electro-catalysts and the oxygen adsorption model [64,65]. In particular, there are three potential pathways in which ORR can occur (Fig. 2c): the peroxo mechanism, the associative mechanism, and the dissociative mechanism [66,67]. During the peroxo mechanism, the interaction between the metallic centers and oxygen does not result in the cleavage of the OO bond. Instead, it follows a two-electron reduction mechanism that gives rise to the generation of hydrogen peroxide. For the associative mechanism, each metallic center binds to an oxygen molecule. This binding makes it challenging for hydrogen peroxide to be detached from the surface of the electro-catalyst, eventually leading to the formation of water as the final product. In the dissociative mechanism, the robust bonding between oxygen and metallic centers enables oxygen molecules to dissociate directly in adsorption positions. This process follows four-electron reduction, which produces water. In these three reduction pathways, different adsorbed oxygen-containing species, like O*, O2*, OH*, and OOH* (with * referring to catalytically active positions), serve as intermediates formed within each stage of reactions. Concurrently, the reactivity of each stage is notably affected by the adsorption strength of the oxygenated species mentioned above on the surface of electro-catalysts [66,68–71]. Particularly, when such oxygenated species exhibit robust adsorption strength, it will hinder the desorption of OH* and O* intermediates. When such oxygenated species display weak adsorption, it significantly restricts the adsorption and dissociation of O2. Thus, an ideal ORR electro-catalyst should possess neither too weak nor too strong adsorption strength for intermediates. Generally, the density functional theory (DFT) method is utilized to give an understanding of the assessment of the free energies of the intermediate products on the surface of electro-catalysts [72–75]. Nørskov's research team [76,77] demonstrated a volcano plot, which would offer helpful direction for rationally designing effective oxygen reduction nanocatalysts. In their research, the connection between oxygen reduction activity and oxygen adsorption energy (ΔEO) of different transition metal elements was estimated using DFT. As shown in the volcano plot, Pt possesses the highest ORR activity, caused by its high oxygen adsorption energy (Fig. 2d). However, Pt's oxygen reduction activity does not approach maximum due to its relatively low oxygen adsorption energy (almost 0.2 eV). It was reported that Pt's ORR activity could be improved when combined with other transition metal components by modifying its adsorption energy. 3 Current issues with single and binary ORR catalysts Monometallic Pt has been widely considered the most favorable cathode electro-catalyst for fuel cell systems. Even though single Pt catalysts perform better than other metal elements, their electro-catalytic effectiveness and stability still lack the required practical application standards, leaving considerable room for improvement. Numerous approaches have been suggested for more effectively optimizing surface energies and increasing stability to boost their ORR efficacy for commercial viability. At first, investigations focused on minimizing the amount of Pt or replacing it to bring down overall expenses [79–82]. There have been a lot of reports regarding the development of ORR electro-catalysts for better activity. Even so, it is still challenging to make these catalysts in sufficient quantities while ensuring the stability required for real industrial applications [83,84]. Binary alloyed catalysts were examined and produced by utilizing less costly transition metals to lower the prices associated with electro-catalyst fabrication and achieve better ORR activity and stability compared to single metal materials. The improved electro-catalytic activity observed in binary catalysts has been clarified by in-depth theoretical investigations. The boosted oxygen reduction properties in binary catalysts are commonly ascribed to ligand, strain, and collective effects, which effectively modify the electronic construction of catalysts [5,85–87]. Changing the d-band center results in a corresponding alteration of the binding energies for reactants and oxygenated species adsorbed on active positions like O*, OH*, and OOH* [67,68]. Because it is difficult to directly examine intermediates during processes, unraveling the reaction mechanism through experiments poses a significant challenge. Although numerous catalysts have been documented, only a small fraction have been employed in commercial applications. For instance, the transportation industry, which represents a major segment of fuel cell marketing, has chosen to use simple alloy materials instead of nanocatalysts with meticulously tailored morphological structures [84,88]. This is because the intricate morphological nanostructures typically do not remain durable throughout continuous operation in actual fuel cell systems, especially under harsh circumstances and at high temperatures [89–91]. Owing to the inherently lower resistance of other alloying metallic elements to acids and oxidizing environments compared to single metallic catalysts, leachable metals within binary catalysts unavoidably dissolve during catalytic processes. Consequently, enhancing catalyst tolerance to degradation under continuous operational conditions remains a significant issue. By considering the mechanism of metal dissolution in binary alloy materials, the incorporation of a third metallic element into binary alloyed catalysts to make ternary systems can definitively address the previously mentioned durability concerns. Areas with weak structural configurations and elevated surface energies are where degradation begins. A simple approach entails adopting the "blocking agent" principle, wherein more durable metals like Mo and Au can be employed to obstruct the positions [92,93]. Nevertheless, this strategy may negatively impact catalytic abilities. This is because areas with elevated surface energies also represent the most active positions during electro-catalysis. Consequently, in addition to physical modifications, it is necessary to chemically alter the inherent characteristics, especially with the improvement of binary alloyed samples. On the other hand, a thorough theory concerning the functions of third metallic elements in such constructions has not yet developed because of the scarcity of multicomponent catalysts. Hence, we emphasize the possibility of using ternary nanostructured catalysts as promising ORR materials for fuel cells. 4 Application of different ternary catalysts for ORR in half-cells Over the last several decades, various single and binary nanocatalysts have been explored [94,95]. Noble metal loadings in catalysts are considerably reduced through combination with other transition metals. Lately, numerous applicable additions of third metallic constituents to binary nanostructures have been developed to further enhance the oxygen reduction ability of catalysts [96,97]. The addition of a third metal in ternary catalysts for ORR produces varying influences depending on the specific metals chosen, their properties, and the composition of catalysts. Scientists often conduct thorough experimental and computational studies to investigate the impact of varied metal compositions on ORR catalytic activity. As of now, different metallic elements (like Pd, Co, Ni, Cu, and Rh) and carbonaceous supporting materials (like carbon black, carbon nanotubes (CNTs), and graphene (G)) have been employed to make ternary nanostructured catalysts [98–100]. It has been extensively reported that ternary nanocatalysts show impressive ORR catalytic capability and durability because of the synergistic interactions of strain and ligand effects [101–103]. According to the preparation conditions and synthesis procedures described earlier in the literature, ternary catalysts can be categorized as support-free ternary catalysts and supported ternary catalysts. 4.1 Support-free ternary catalysts Incorporating noble metals with other inexpensive components is the most effective technique to promote ORR capability without the addition of support, leading to the generation of support-free catalysts [104–106]. Typically, it is achieved through altered electronic constructions and synergetic effects among multiple constituents. The ORR catalytic efficiency of support-free ternary nanocatalysts is profoundly influenced by their morphologies, trimetallic compositions, and structures [107–109]. It is known that ternary catalysts possess enhanced catalytic performance with respect to their unary and binary analogs, which are mostly produced via the electro-deposition method, galvanic replacement reaction, one-pot wet-chemical reduction method, etc. For example, a series of trimetallic Pt-Ru-Ir nanocatalysts with different atomic ratios of Pt and Ir (Pt0.5Ru4.0Ir4.5, Pt1.5Ru4.0Ir3.5, Pt2.5Ru4.0Ir2.5, Pt3.5Ru4.0Ir1.5, and Pt4.5Ru4.0Ir0.5) were developed by Morales et al. [104] using a chemical reduction process. Ruthenium (Ru) has long been regarded as a highly efficient nanocatalyst for oxygen reduction compared with Ir and Pt; thus, a large and constant mass of Ru was employed in all Pt-Ru-Ir nanostructures. The prepared catalysts indicated poor crystallinity due to the construction of various phases as well as high nanoparticle aggregation with an increase in Pt content. The optimal Pt3.5Ru4.0Ir1.5 nanocatalyst exhibited decent oxygen reduction activities with a Tafel slope of −65 mV/dec and an excellent transfer coefficient (α) in acidic electrolytes. Park et al. [110] reported the preparation of ternary PtNiCu electro-catalysts with different compositions through a facile electro-deposition method. Some characterization techniques were used to assess the ORR electro-catalytic activities and durability of the nanocatalysts. The authors concluded that the composition of alloyed samples markedly altered their crystalline properties and morphologies. The electro-chemical results clearly demonstrated that the PtCu and the optimum PtNiCu samples displayed about 1.1 and 5.5 times better specific activity (SA) toward oxygen reduction compared with pure Pt in the presence of phosphate anions. Moreover, this ternary nanocatalyst exhibited a ca. 160 mV greater half-wave potential (E1/2) relative to the pure Pt catalyst. The main reason for the improved ORR properties of PtCuNi alloy electro-catalysts can be attributed to Pt's electronic configuration changes. The electron-abundant condition of Pt within the alloyed sample is considered advantageous for reducing Pt-O bond strength. In addition to the crucial function of the compositional ratio of the metal constituents, the structural and morphological characteristics of the ternary nanomaterials substantially impact electro-catalytic performance [111,112]. Nanospherical dendritic structures, among other morphological features, possess increased surface areas and multiple defective regions, with enhanced exposure to substantial reactive positions that are easily accessible to reactants. This improves the electron and mass transfer processes, which can contribute to a noticeable improvement in the ORR. Duan et al. described the fabrication of trimetallic Pt-Ru-Pd nanospheres (Pt-Ru-Pd NSs) along with their application in oxygen reduction [32]. They fabricated porous dendritic Pt-Ru-Pd NSs through a simple aqueous technique in the presence of ascorbic acid and hexadecylpyridinium chloride (HDPC) as the reductant and the structure guiding factor, respectively (Fig. 3 a). The authors found that the as-fabricated Pt-Ru-Pd NSs demonstrated superior performance for catalyzing oxygen reduction in alkaline environments. The Pt-Ru-Pd NSs catalyst showed an onset potential (Eonset) of 0.93 V as well as E1/2 of 0.85 V vs. RHE, much better compared to those obtained for Pt-Pd NSs (0.90 and 0.84 V), Pd-Ru NSs (0.89 and 0.84 V), and Pt/C catalyst (0.91 and 0.82 V), as revealed in Fig. 3b. Remarkably, the resultant Pt-Ru-Pd NSs sample possessed higher current densities compared with those of Pt-Pd NSs, Pd-Ru NSs, and Pt/C catalysts. In addition, after durability tests, the resultant Pt-Ru-Pd NSs sample indicated slight shifts in both E1/2 and Eonset, together with similar current densities within the entire potential range. In other words, this trimetallic catalyst revealed steeply enhanced durability for oxygen reduction (Fig. 3c). The improved electro-catalytic capabilities and impressive, long-lasting performance of the prepared Pt-Ru-Pd NSs for oxygen reduction come from their distinctive dendritic sphere structure. This structure affords increased active positions, which are readily available to reacting substances. Moreover, electronic modifications and strain interactions among the three metallic components in the nanocatalyst also enhance ORR performance. This research proposes valuable directions for the construction of effective trimetallic alloy catalysts for ORR. Another investigation into ORR on trimetallic catalysts was reported by the same research team [113]. They utilized a simple, dynamic-templated route to prepare interconnected Pt-Pb-Pd ultrathin nanowires (Pt-Pb-Pd NWs) using octylphenoxypolyethoxyethanol (NP-40) as the structure guiding factor. The authors showed that both the quantity of NP-40 and the type of precursor were crucial for catalyst preparation. The elemental mapping images derived from transmission electron microscopy (STEM) for the Pt-Pb-Pd NWs catalyst confirmed that Pt, Pd, and Pb metallic elements were consistently distributed within the sample. This uniform distribution demonstrated that ternary alloyed nanomaterials were successfully formed. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the ternary sample showed four diffraction peaks located between those observed in standard Pt, Pd, and Pb positions, providing additional evidence for the formation of alloyed Pt-Pb-Pd NWs. The studied Pt-Pb-Pd NWs revealed superior ORR electro-catalytic performance with greater current density and E1/2 (5.24 mA/cm2 and 0.891 V vs. RHE) compared with those of Pt-Pb NWs (3.16 mA/cm2 and 0.845 V), Pt-Pd NWs (4.99 mA/cm2 and 0.864 V), Pd-Pb NWs (4.41 mA/cm2 and 0.822 V), and carbon-supported Pt catalyst (5.03 mA/cm2 and 0.829 V) in alkaline solutions. Moreover, the Eonset (0.993 V) of the prepared ternary sample was more positive than those of Pt-Pb NWs (0.948 V), Pt-Pd NWs (0.972 V), Pd-Pb NWs (0.894 V), and commercial Pt/C (0.895 V). The enhanced electro-catalytic capabilities of Pt-Pb-Pd NWs in oxygen reduction can be caused by the combination of electronic modifications and collaborative effects among three metals as well as the distinctive interconnected nanowire constructions, which offer a substantial quantity of readily reachable active positions for reacting substances. Li et al. [114] described a facile, efficient one-pot synthesis approach for the high-yield fabrication of ternary Pt-Pd-Ni mesoporous nanospheres (Pt-Pd-Ni MNs) by using L-ascorbic acid (AA) as the reductant factor and the surfactant F127 as the structure guiding factor toward ORR in acidic environments. As seen in Fig. 4 a–c, the resultant ternary Pt-Pd-Ni catalysts displayed well-developed mesoporous nanostructures and narrow pore-size distributions (between 100 and 120 nm). The elemental mapping images of the Pt-Pd-Ni MNs sample confirmed the homogenous dispersion of Pt, Ni, and Pd in the catalyst, demonstrating the generation of ternary alloyed nanostructures. It was reported that the Pt-Pd-Ni MNs material had the superior oxygen reduction ability with an E1/2 of ∼0.98 V and an Eonset of 1.00 V vs. RHE compared to Pt-Pd-Ni nanodendrites (PtPdNi NDs), Pt-Pd MNs, and Pt/C catalysts (Fig. 4d). The porous construction of ternary Pt-Pd-Ni nanospheres could afford many exposed reactive positions, efficient electron transfer, and rapid mass transport. Compared with Pt-Pd-Ni NDs, Pt-Pd MNs, and carbon-supported Pt catalysts, the Pt-Pd-Ni MNs synthesized in this research held great promise for oxygen reduction due to their unique structural features characterized by a significant level of mesoporosity and openness, together with their specific composition merits (trimetallic alloyed structure). Later, the same research group [108] developed a wet-chemical approach to fabricate ternary Pt-Pd-Co mesoporous nanoparticles (Pt-Pd-Co MNs) for ORR. The suggested preparation technique could be conducted in aqueous solutions without using hard templates or organic solvents, producing Pt-Pd-Co MNs with homogenous morphological features. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images illustrated that the average size of Pt-Pd-Co nanoparticles was about 105 nm with a narrow size distribution. XRD analysis revealed a noticeable upward shift in the positions of the diffraction peaks of the ternary sample compared with Pt alone. This shift confirmed the incorporation of Co and Pd metals into the Pt lattice. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra demonstrated a minor displacement toward greater binding energy in the Pt0 4f5/2 (74.8 eV) and 4f7/2 (71.5 eV) peaks of the Pt-Pd-Co MNs relative to the typical values for pure metallic Pt (4f5/2 (74.5 eV) and 4f7/2 (71.2 eV)), suggesting an amendment in the electronic configuration of Pt because of forming alloyed structures with Pd and Co. The highly porous Pt-Pd-Co MNs showed improved E1/2 (0.93 V) for oxygen reduction compared with those of binary Pt-Pd MNs (0.91 V) and carbon-supported Pt (0.87 V) electro-catalysts. Remarkably, the Tafel slope observed for Pt-Pd-Co MNs (56.9 mV dec−1) was smaller than that of both Pt-Pd MNs (59.2 mV dec−1) and carbon-supported Pt catalyst (66.3 mV dec−1), indicating the higher propensity of Pt-Pd-Co MNs for facilitating the oxygen reduction. The authors concluded that adding Pd and Co atoms to Pt's lattice to make ternary alloyed Pt-Pd-Co MNs could alter Pt's d-band energy level and electronic structure. Such alterations could reduce the strength of the interaction between oxygenated intermediates and Pt, ultimately improving oxygen reduction catalytic ability. Considering the intrinsic electronic configuration and position of the Pd d-band center, Pd-Ru nanomaterials exhibit certain ORR limitations. Based on recent reports, the electro-catalytic capability and durability of nanocatalysts for oxygen reduction can be substantially enhanced by combining Pd and Au. This improvement comes from Au's ability to efficiently optimize the adsorption of oxygen on Pd surfaces, thereby mitigating Pd dissolution [115–117]. For example, Wang et al. [118] employed a facile one-step reduction method to prepare Pd-Au-Ru nanospine assemblies (Pd-Au-Ru NSAs), using DM-970 as a surfactant and KBr as a structure-directing agent. The fabricated hyperbranched nanostructure possessed adequate reactive positions, available transfer channels, and outstanding resistance to the detachment, dissolution, migration, and aggregation of the catalysts. The authors suggested that the addition of Au and Ru elements to the Pd lattice would lead to a change in Pd d-band energy, resulting in the weakening of oxygenated species binding to Pd, hence increasing oxygen adsorption on its surface. The Pd-Au-Ru NSAs showed improved ORR activity and durability compared to commercial carbon-supported Pt catalysts in alkaline conditions. The presence of three different metallic constituents and their hyper-branched nanostructure can explain the improved durability of Pd-Au-Ru NSAs in ORR. These characteristics notably impede the dissolving, accumulating, and Oswald ripening processes of the nanocatalysts. The preparation method in this work provides a possible way of designing hyperbranched multimetallic nanocatalysts for electro-catalytic applications. When Au is integrated with additional transition metal constituents, oxygen reduction capabilities can be improved because of efficiently altering the electronic configurations of alloyed catalysts [119]. In this regard, Chen et al. [106] used L-proline as the structure-directing factor and ascorbic acid (AA) as the reductant to fabricate homogenous ternary Au-Pt-Pd nanodendrites (NDs) via a facile synthesis tactic. The high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) analysis revealed well-defined lattice patterns with inter-planar spacing distances measuring 0.234 and 0.233 nm, attributed to the (111) crystal facets of face-centered cubic (fcc) Au-Pt-Pd alloys. Also, the 0.202 nm value refers to the (200) crystal facets. This observation significantly confirmed the generation of alloyed Au-Pt-Pd NDs. The XRD patterns of Au-Pt-Pd NDs exhibited four characteristic peaks corresponding to the (111), (200), (220), and (311) facets of Au-Pt-Pd nanocrystals situated between those of standard Pd, Pt, and Au. These findings proved the successful construction of ternary alloy structures. In comparison with Au-Pd nanocrystals (NCs, 3.9 m2/g), Au-Pt NCs (21.8 m2/g), Pd black (8.3 m2/g), and Pt black (20.9 m2/g), the synthesized Au-Pt-Pd NDs had the highest electro-chemical active surface area (ECSA) (27.6 m2/g), which provided them with remarkably enhanced oxygen reduction performances. Besides, the prepared Au-Pt-Pd NDs revealed E1/2 of 0.924 V and Eonset of 0.998 V, much better than those obtained for Au-Pd NCs (0.929 and 0.975 V), Au-Pt NCs (0.913 and 0.917 V), Pd black (0.870 and 0.915 V), and Pt black (0.891 and 0.945 V). The current density for Au-Pt-Pd NDs was much higher than that for Au-Pd NCs, making it ideal for practical applications. It could be concluded that the ternary sample manifested striking electro-catalytic performance compared with its binary and unary counterparts, owing to the electronic modifications and synergistic interactions between the three metallic elements. In another study, ternary Au@PdPt porous nanowires (pNWs) with core-shell nanoarchitectures were described by Liu et al. [120], who employed a simple method to improve the electro-catalytic activity of samples using Au incorporation into Pt-containing catalysts (Fig. 5 a). As displayed in Fig. 5b and c, Au@PdPt catalysts exhibited even nanowire morphologies with nanopore surfaces. The resulting porous core-shell constructions showed substantially enhanced oxygen reduction performance thanks to their large surface areas and more reactant transmitting channels (Fig. 5d). The Au@PdPt pNWs exhibited a limiting current density of 5.62 mA/cm2, which was higher compared with that for mesoporous PdPt nanoparticles (mPdPt NPs, 5.33 mA/cm2) and carbon-supported Pt catalyst (5.24 mA/cm2). Furthermore, the Tafel slope value of Au@PdPt pNWs (55 mV dec−1) was lower than that of mesoporous PdPt nanoparticles (mPdPt NPs, 64 mV dec−1), and commercial carbon-supported Pt catalyst (66 mV dec−1), signifying that the rate-controlling stage in this sample is the first electron transfer process (Fig. 5e). After accelerated durability test (ADT) tests, the decline in E1/2 for Au@PdPt pNWs was just 10 mV, a considerably lesser decrease compared to the deteriorations observed in mPdPt NPs (19 mV) and carbon-supported Pt catalyst (26 mV). These outcomes suggested that Au@PdPt pNWs displayed superior durability during the oxygen reduction process. The authors proposed that improvements in electro-catalytic abilities and oxygen reduction kinetics could be explained by three primary factors. First, the combination of Pt, with unfilled d-orbitals, and Pd, with fully occupied d-orbitals, to form alloyed structures. Second, the utilization of Au atoms segregated in the Au core to fill defective positions within the shell layers. Third, the benefits of employing three different metals to accelerate oxygen adsorption and catalytic activation. In 2018, Huihua et al. [23] developed an ultrasonic irradiation strategy to produce Co-Fe-Pd nanocatalysts, which demonstrated excellent ORR performance due to the trimetallic micro-alloying influence. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) studies of the Co5Fe2Pd1 catalyst showed that nanosized particles were uniformly distributed with an average diameter of around 3–5 nm. The XPS findings specified that Co, Fe, and Pd within the Co5Fe2Pd1 catalyst were predominantly observed in the metallic state. The nanoparticulated Co5Fe2Pd catalysts displayed the most positive Eonset compared with those of the Co5Pd1 (0.89 V), Co5Fe2 (0.74 V), Co (0.68 V), and Pt/C (0.94 V vs. RHE) catalysts. This observation indicated that additional active positions could arise from ternary synergistic interactions. Interestingly, the nanoparticulated Co5Fe2Pd1 catalysts possessed superior ORR ability and methanol resistance relative to Co5Pd1, Co5Fe2, Co, and well-established commercially available Pt/C catalysts and followed the 4e− route for catalyzing oxygen reduction in alkaline solutions. Consequently, Co5Fe2Pd1 catalysts fabricated by ultrasonic irradiation can be regarded as favorable cathode materials in direct methanol alkaline fuel cell systems. In the work of Luo et al. [121], trimetallic alloyed Co-Au-Pd nanocatalysts (Co-Au-Pd NCs) were designed using co-reduction and successive reduction techniques. A homogenous distribution of solid alloy nanostructures (Co-Au-Pd-1 NCs) was formed for ORR. The trimetallic alloy nanocatalysts (Co-Au-Pd-3 NCs) resulting from the successive reduction process included several distinctive hollow and solid nanoparticles, which showed more promising ORR performance than other catalysts. The initial trimetallic Co-Au-Pd NCs displayed improved oxygen reduction capabilities relative to bimetallic Au-Pd NCs. The dealloyed Co-Au-Pd-3 NCs presented 1.15, 1.27, and 1.23 folds higher SA (298.15 μA cm−2) compared to that of the dealloyed Co-Au-Pd-1 NCs, Au-Pd-4, and Au-Pd-5 NCs. After the dealloying procedure, the obtained Co-Au-Pd NCs exhibited outstandingly boosted oxygen reduction ability because of their higher exposed reactive centers and unique nanostructures. Other trimetallic nanocatalysts have also been explored to determine their effectiveness in oxygen reduction catalysis. In this context, Zhao et al. [122] proposed a simple tactic for the preparation of Ru-M-Pt (M = Ni, Cu, Co, and Fe) nanodendrite materials toward ORR (Fig. 6 a). As depicted in Fig. 6b–g, ternary samples fabricated in the presence of oleylamine (OAm) and 1-Octadecene (ODE) showed clearly spherical-shaped nanoparticles with dendritic morphological structures. The Ru-Ni-Pt nanodendritic catalyst had an average diameter of almost 30 nm and displayed an impressively consistent shape. Furthermore, high-angle annular dark-field scanning TEM (HAADF-STEM) studies and the corresponding elemental mappings of the Ru-Ni-Pt catalyst revealed nanodendritic particles, together with the uniform scattering of three metallic constituents in this sample. The prepared trimetallic nanomaterials disclosed improved ORR catalytic activity relative to bimetallic Pt-containing alloys and the Pt/C electro-catalyst, which could be associated with the altered electronic arrangements of Pt along with the synergic interactions between trimetals (Fig. 6h). As displayed in Fig. 6i–k, the integration of Ni species into Pt-Ru nanocatalysts resulted in increased electro-catalytic capabilities, lower charge transfer resistance, and higher durability toward oxygen reduction compared to other samples. The authors believed that the extremely active and hierarchical catalysts that can be made using this efficient and simple method would have a broad range of applications. In follow-up research, Li et al. [123] illustrated the fabrication of trimetallic Te-Cu-Pt nanowires (NWs) using a galvanic replacement process and examined their electro-catalytic behavior for catalyzing oxygen reduction. In their study, Te NWs acted as reductants and sacrificial templates to produce trimetallic Te-Cu-Pt NWs. Their electro-chemical results revealed that the Te-Cu-Pt NWs had larger ECSAs (20.1 m2/g) than bimetallic Te-Pt NTs (15.5 m2/g) and single Pt (14.2 m2/g) catalysts. Moreover, the MA and SA of Te-Cu-Pt NWs (59 mA/mg Pt and 0.29 mA/cm2 Pt) were greater than those of bimetallic Te-Pt NTs (44 mA/mg Pt and 0.25 mA/cm2 Pt) and single Pt (16 mA/mg Pt and 0.11 mA/cm2 Pt) catalysts. It has been determined that the alloy structures formed among Pt, Cu, and Te could significantly decrease the d-band position of Pt due to geometric and electronic effects, which lowered the bonding energy between Pt and oxygenated intermediates, thereby increasing their ORR electro-catalytic capability. As mentioned in this section, support-free ternary nanostructured materials, such as nanoparticles, nanowires, and nanodendrites, have great potential for ORR catalysis. Table 1 presents some reported support-free ternary electro-catalysts in the literature. 4.2 Supported ternary catalysts Heterostructured nanomaterials with multiple interfaces provide additional possibilities for tuning the electronic properties of ternary catalysts and their affinity for intermediates alongside the strain and ligand effects among three diverse metallic constituents. Introducing suitable supports can further increase nanoparticle dispersion, improve electronic conductivity, and boost durability resulting from favorable charge transfer between metal and supporting materials [134,135]. Up to now, a variety of carbonous materials (carbon black, carbon nanotubes, graphene, etc.), metal carbides, and metal oxides have been investigated as efficient catalyst substrates for ORR [136–143]. Carbon materials are promising matrices for anchoring ternary nanocatalysts thanks to their high conductivity, large surface areas, and desirable chemical attributes [94,144]. Notably, different carbon-supported ternary nanocatalysts have been examined to promote ORR performances of fuel cell systems [24,137,145–147]. Recent studies by Wang et al. [24] proposed a feasible strategy to construct PtRhNi truncated triangular nanoflakes (TA-NFs) loaded on commercial carbon for ORR. As seen in Fig. 7 a, these alloyed materials displayed the same positively shifted linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) curves in comparison to the carbon-supported Pt catalyst, and the PtRhNi TA-NFs sample possessed a remarkable E1/2 of 0.94 V vs. RHE, superior to that of PtNi TA-NFs/C (0.93 V), PtRhNi nanoparticles (NPs) (0.91 V), and carbon-supported Pt (0.88 V) catalysts. The authors found that the prepared PtRhNi TA-NFs sample, which benefited from such a unique nanostructure, manifested 1.64, 2.03, and 6.9 times greater mass activity (MA) (0.92 A mg−1 Pt) toward ORR than that of the PtNi TA-NFs, PtRhNi NPs, and carbon-supported Pt catalysts, respectively. Moreover, as indicated in Fig. 7b, the PtRhNi TA-NFs catalyst exhibited negligible E1/2 losses (just 10 mV), and the MA declined by about 20 % over potential cycling in ADT. The improved stability of PtRhNi TA-NFs compared to electro-catalysts with similar nanostructures suggests that incorporating suitable proportions of third components (Rh) is necessary for augmenting stability. Significantly, the enhanced oxygen reduction capability of PtRhNi TA-NFs originates from the integration of oxophilic metals and transition metals, which alter Pt's electronic properties. This modification weakens intermediate adsorption onto the nanocatalyst, enhancing electro-catalytic performance. Their study revealed a practical approach for fabricating high-performing bifunctional Pt-based materials for oxygen reduction in advanced fuel cell applications. In order to develop cheaper nanomaterials by diminishing Pt content, with ORR performance close to monometallic Pt, and to clarify the connections between nanostructures, morphologies, and electro-catalytic properties of catalysts, Güldür et al. [149] constructed Pt6CuFe/C, Pt6AgFe/C, and Pt6AgCu/C samples through a wet impregnation-reduction strategy and low-temperature heat-treating process. In their study, the obtained trimetallic nanocatalysts were examined using physical and electro-chemical methods. Based on XRD analyses, Pt's average particle sizes were estimated to be 3–4 nm. The authors stated that the Pt6AgFe/C sample exhibited the greatest MA (29.1 mA mg−1 at 0.7 V vs. SCE) and the largest ECSA (557 cm2 mg−1 Pt) among the three investigated materials. The value of ECSA for Pt6AgFe/C lay within the favorable range, surpassing that of numerous recently described Pt ternary and binary nanocatalysts. Xiong and colleagues found that PtCo/C binary electro-catalysts had ECSA values from 490 to 630 cm2 mg−1 [150]. In another investigation, the ECSA of heat-treated PtCu/XC-72 catalysts ranged from 241 to 423 cm2 mg−1 based on heat-treated temperatures [151]. The ECSA of PtFe/C catalysts fabricated by Li et al. varied from 143 to 636 cm2 mg−1 [152]. Their findings confirmed that the introduction of Fe and Ag into the Pt nanocatalyst can increase Pt utilization. Recently, a straightforward one-pot preparation technique followed by heat treatment has been used by Xiao et al. [153] to construct trimetallic PtCuFe/C catalysts with low Pt content for ORR. A Pt-rich shell was produced on the PtCuFe nanocatalyst surface via dealloying treatments. The conditions of the dealloying process had a profound impact on ORR efficiency. They claimed that the improved oxygen reduction ability of the PtCuFe/C material could be related to the dissolution of Fe and Cu on the surface of Pt. The D-Pt2CuFe/C-150 nanocatalyst demonstrated a three-fold increase in MA (0.99 A/mg Pt at 0.9 V vs. RHE) compared with that of a commercial Pt3Co1/C (TKK) catalyst. After 5000 ADT cycles, the D-Pt1CuFe/C-150 sample exhibited the most negligible loss (7.6 %) in ORR activity, while the TKK nanocatalyst displayed much more pronounced degradation (∼29 %) under identical circumstances. The superior ORR electro-catalytic properties of the D-Pt2CuFe/C-150 nanocatalyst result from the compressive strain applied to the Pt shells. This strain can cause a shift in the Pt d-band position, leading to more modification of binding strengths for oxygen-containing intermediates. It is possible to make homogenous ternary alloyed materials at a specific atomic proportion using binary-phase diagrams for Pt-Ag, Pt-Cu, and Ag-Cu. Single-phase materials generally have highly stable characteristics. For example, Zhou et al. [33] fabricated Pt-Cu-Ag/C alloyed catalysts by varying the amount of Ag with a borohydride chemical reduction process. The optimum Pt-Cu-Ag/C nanocatalyst with a 3:10:1 atomic composition of Pt:Cu:Ag (denoted as Pt-Cu-Ag/C (3:10:1)) displayed the highest ORR electro-catalytic performance among all the studied samples. The transferred electron numbers of the ORR for Pt-Cu-Ag/C (3:10:1) and Pt-Cu/C were 4.0 and 2.8, respectively, which suggested that Pt-Cu-Ag/C (3:10:1) outperformed the Pt-Cu/C sample. The limiting current density of the optimum ternary Pt-Cu-Ag/C (3:10:1) catalyst (Pt metal loading: 9.29 µg Pt/cm2) reached 3.85 mA/cm2 after 200 cyclic voltammetry (CV) circles. In contrast to the Pt-M alloyed nanocatalysts described in previous studies, one additional pair of redox peaks corresponding to Ag can be observed in the CV curves of the Pt-Cu-Ag/C samples. It was concluded that the smaller particle sizes, the structural alteration, and the more accessible active centers created by the addition of Ag within a Pt-Cu-Ag/C (3:10:1) nanocatalyst contributed to superior oxygen reduction ability. The XPS, TEM, and XRD results showed that the exceptional effectiveness of the Pt-Cu-Ag/C (3:10:1) sample could be due to three reasons. First, the smaller particle sizes led to a higher dispersion of Pt atoms on the surface of the catalyst. Second, Ag incorporation caused crystal alterations, increasing Pt's catalytic ability. Finally, the presence of dissolved Ag and CuO on the surface of alloyed nanoparticles during CV cycling tests exposed more Pt atoms on nanoparticle surfaces. The integration of smaller-sized elements into the Pt lattice can cause lattice shrinkage and change the arrangement of the nanocatalysts' surface electrons, adjusting their catalytic ability for catalyzing oxygen reduction. In comparison with other well-researched metallic elements, zirconium (Zr), with an atomic radius of 1.60 Å, serves as an ideal metal for amending the electronic construction of the nanocatalyst in Pt-containing alloyed materials. In this regard, Zeng et al. [148] investigated the synthesis of PtZrNi nanorods (PtZrNi NRs) loaded on the carbon substrate using a simple wet-chemical process to obtain superior catalytic properties for oxygen reduction. Electro-chemical analyses indicated that PtZrNi NRs possess markedly superior catalytic capabilities in ORR catalysis. Benefiting from the one-dimensional (1D) ultrathin structure, the ECSA of PtZrNi NRs/C (77.8 m2 g−1) was larger than that of PtZr NRs/C (58.5 m2 g−1) and commercial Pt/C (70.2 m2 g−1). In acidic conditions, the studied PtZrNi NRs exhibited better MA of 0.755 A mg−1 Pt at 0.9 V for ORR, which was 4.7 folds higher than that of the carbon-supported Pt catalyst. Moreover, the ternary PtZrNi NRs demonstrated enhanced MA of 3.216 A mg−1 Pt, which was 34.6 folds higher than that of the carbon-supported Pt catalyst in alkaline conditions. Since the d-band center is regarded as a valuable parameter for estimating adsorption strength, DFT calculations were carried out to compute the projected d-density of states (PDOS) for PtZrNi (111), PtZr (111), and Pt (111) surfaces. As illustrated in Fig. 7c, the incorporation of Ni and Zr elements caused a lower d-band position relative to Pt alone. These results implied weaker adsorption of oxygenated intermediates because of the stronger anti-bond state occupancy between the ternary catalyst and the adsorbate material. According to experimental measurements and DFT simulations, surface electronic configurations were effectively optimized through trimetallic alloy formation. Remarkably, the 1D ultrathin construction could enhance ORR durability by improving the composition and structural integrity of the catalyst. Gao et al. [154] constructed carbon-supported PtFeNi nanoparticles by incorporating high quantities of Fe and Ni metallic elements via a microwave-assisted polyol technique (Fig. 8 a). Noticeably, improvements in the ORR electro-catalytic abilities of the studied Pt-containing materials can be related to the addition of Fe and Ni metals. Chemically ordered nanostructures in acidic environments can make ternary nanocatalysts extremely stable through subsequent annealing procedures. Furthermore, the insertion of a large amount of Fe and Ni metallic constituents would contribute to reduced Pt utilization and lower prices without affecting the electro-catalytic performance. Based on the XRD results, the even distribution of nanosized particles (5 nm) and face-centered tetragonal (fct) structures can increase the PtFeNi/C catalyst's capability. After annealing at 675 °C, the obtained Pt2Fe3Ni3/C-675 nanocatalyst exhibited striking oxygen reduction performances in acidic solutions, as demonstrated by an MA of 0.73 A mg−1 Pt and a positive E1/2 (Fig. 8b and c). In addition, the optimum Pt2Fe3Ni3/C-675 sample had higher stability than Pt/C in ADT tests. After ADT, TEM and HRTEM images of the optimum ternary sample showed a homogeneous distribution of the nanoparticles over the surface of the supporting material. These observations can be attributed to the robust interplay between nanoparticles and the substrate. A chemically ordered arrangement and the protection provided by the Pt shells explain the preservation of the superlattice configuration. This may result from the dispersion of Pt within the Pt2Fe3Ni3/C-675 nanoparticles throughout the heat-treatment process. Furthermore, Knani et al. [155] employed an impregnation process using NaBH4 as a reductant to make trimetallic PtCoSn nanoparticles deposited on carbon substrates. Oxygen reduction performances of prepared samples were evaluated in acidic media. Physical analyses confirmed the generation of alloyed structures between Pt and other metallic components (Sn and Co) in the Pt85Co5Sn10/C catalyst with small particle sizes (around 3.4 nm). According to rotating disk electrode (RDE) measurements and Koutecky-Levich (K-L) analyses, the ORR activities of alloyed samples follow this sequence: PtCo/C < Pt/C < PtSn/C < PtCoSn/C. Compared to the binary PtCo/C catalyst, the ORR capability of the ternary PtCoSn/C sample can be considerably enhanced by introducing tiny amounts of Sn. This enhancement in ORR performance could arise from an alteration in the oxophilicity of the ternary nanocatalyst. It has also been revealed that oxygen reduction on the investigated catalyst proceeded by a four-electron path with water as the main product. The authors believed that the synergy of structural and electronic effects might be responsible for the impressive performance of PtCoSn/C in oxygen reduction catalysis. For the majority of reported alloyed nanocatalysts, an enhancement was observed because of the combination with other metals. Lokanathan et al. [156] synthesized ternary PtNiCo alloyed nanostructures using a facile solvothermal technique followed by heat treatment under reducing circumstances (Fig. 9 a). The PtNiCo/C nanoflower geometries were detected after 16 h (marked as PtNiCo-16h/C), while other structures like nanoparticulated catalysts appeared at various stages during the procedure. As presented in Fig. 9b, TEM analysis revealed the fabrication of flowerlike structures, and the diameter of these nanoflowers was approximately 25 nm. The prepared PtNiCo-16h/C alloy nanoflower yielded 12 folds higher SA (2.47 mA/cm2) than that of carbon-supported Pt catalyst (0.2 mA/cm2). The outstanding ORR capability of PtNiCo-16h/C may arise from the introduction of Ni and Co elements into the lattice of Pt. This incorporation can cause a contraction in the lattice structure (strain effect) while also modifying Pt's electronic structure by shifting its d-band downward. These effects have been further confirmed by XRD and XPS analyses. In addition, nanoflowers with (111) crystalline planes on their surface demonstrated extraordinary effectiveness in enhancing oxygen reduction kinetics. After stability experiments, the PtNiCo-16h/C nanocatalyst displayed a slightly positive-shifted oxide reduction potential and an increased ECSA compared to its initial activity. These findings indicated an increase in oxygen reduction performance after CV cycling (Fig. 9c). The superior performance of the PtNiCo-16h/C sample relative to carbon-supported Pt catalysts confirmed the retention of Co and Ni, even with a slight dissolution of the surface layer due to increased contraction of the lattice within the ternary alloyed nanocatalyst. Moreover, Shen et al. [157] introduced an approach to improve alloyed nanostructure stability by incorporating a third metal component into the PtNi-based system (Fig. 10 a), supported by DFT computations. According to their theoretical studies, adding indium (In) components to the PtNi alloyed catalyst would efficiently lower the surface energy and increment the atom diffusion energy barriers, which could promote ORR stability through the stabilization of the reactive surfaces and the diminution of internal Ni leaching (Fig. 10b and c). Their results verified that the ternary Pt2In0.2Ni1.8 bulk was more stable than the Pt2Ni2 bulk. As illustrated in Fig. 10d, incorporating In into the PtNi binary structure resulted in a slight shift away from the optimum d-band position area, reducing oxygen reduction performance. These observations may be connected with an unoptimized total Pt:In:Ni composition within the present modeling technique, which could be further amended to achieve the desired d-band positions. Moreover, their findings revealed that these modified oxygen reduction abilities would greatly enhance ternary catalysts' stability. The MA of the binary Pt2Ni2/C alloy dropped to around 76.8 % after accelerated stress tests (ASTs), which implied its low stability. Meanwhile, experimental measurements revealed that the Pt2In0.2Ni1.8/C nanocatalyst possessed the most impressive ORR performance among the fabricated materials. The optimal Pt2In0.2Ni1.8/C alloyed sample exhibited an MA of 0.76 A/mg Pt and about 97.5 % retention of its initial MA during ASTs (Fig. 10e and f). The increased amount of Ni and the improved morphological structure, preserved after AST, suggested slow diffusion of Ni and superior stability, which is consistent with the DFT results. Many researchers have shown that Pd-containing materials are viable nanocatalysts for ORR in fuel cell systems [27,37,158–164]. Unlike Pd-alone catalysts, the prices of Pd-containing nanomaterials can be decreased by combining other transition metals with Pd [86,165–168]. Indeed, the integration of binary Pd systems with third alloying elements induces a synergy of geometric and electronic effects, amending the adsorption and desorption abilities of species on nanocatalysts, thus boosting the ORR electro-catalytic activity of Pd materials [169–171]. As a result, a great deal of effort has been undertaken to develop ternary Pd-containing alloy samples as ORR catalysts in fuel cell devices. For example, Venkateswara Rao et al. [172] synthesized PdCoAu alloyed nanoparticles anchored on carbon through a water-in-oil (w/o) microemulsion system for catalyzing ORR. The w/o microemulsions applied in their research comprised water, Triton X-100, and cyclohexane as the aqueous phase, surfactant, and oil phase, respectively. The XRD analysis revealed the fcc crystalline features of Pd in this sample. Using energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX), the Pd/Co/Au atomic proportion within the heat-treated PdCoAu/C alloy nanocatalyst was verified to be 7:2:1. The PdCoAu/C alloyed sample had about 75 mV lower Eonset for oxygen reduction than Pd alone. The variation in surface activation could explain the differences in Eonset among different heat-treated ternary materials. This phenomenon is closely linked to the scattering and size of nanoparticles. The electro-chemical tests exhibited that the incorporation of alloying components improved the oxygen reduction catalytic activities of the ternary nanocatalysts by preventing the generation of oxygenated intermediates on the surface of Pd due to the decreased density of states at the Pd Fermi level caused by the downshifting of the d-band position. In a recent study by Nie et al. [99], ultrafine trimetallic PtPdCu alloyed nanoparticles supported on CNTs were prepared using a facile surfactant-free solvothermal method for catalyzing ORR. The PtPdCu alloyed nanoparticles (with an average size of about 5 nm) were firmly attached to the surface of CNT because of the small amount of carboxyl groups (2 %) present on the CNT substrate. The ternary PtPdCu/CNTs specified a higher E1/2 of 0.888 V for ORR than PtCu/CNTs (0.833 V), PtPd/CNTs (0.855 V), and carbon-supported Pt (0.829 V) catalysts. Moreover, PtPdCu/CNTs exhibited excellent durability with only a 6 mV loss of E1/2 after 3000 potential cycles in ADT experiments. The prepared PtPdCu/CNTs sample showed much better ORR performance due to the incorporation of ultrafine trimetallic particles, the adjusted d-band positions, the combined impact of Pd and Cu, as well as CNT substrates with excellent conductivity. DFT calculations were also performed to analyze the PDOS of the d-band center of Pt for Pt (111) and PtPdC (111). Their findings indicated a downshift in the d-band center of Pt for both Pt (111) and PtPdC (111) relative to the Fermi level (EF), as presented in Fig. 10g. Besides, DFT analyses verified that alloy generation with Cu and Pd can diminish Pt's d-band position, thereby lowering the binding affinity for intermediates at the Pt points of ternary catalysts, ultimately improving the oxygen reduction properties. This study provides guidance for producing feasible ternary alloy-based nanocatalysts for ORR in fuel cell systems. Recent investigations have suggested that 1D Pt nanoarchitectures show superior oxygen reduction electro-catalytic performance compared to nanoparticulated Pt catalysts because of their bigger smooth surface areas, greater tolerance to degradation, and fewer defect sites and crystal boundaries. Furthermore, 1D nanoarchitectures deposited onto carbonous supporting materials displayed a higher number of contact regions with substrates as well as firmer supports, which contributed to increased conductivity and durability. As an example, Liu et al. [173] prepared homogenous 1D Pt-Pd-Te nanowires loaded on the surface of a carbon foam substrate (Pt-Pd-Te-NWs/CF) utilizing Te as catalyst templates. Morphological analyses confirmed that these ternary metallic nanowires were consistently anchored over the carbon foam surfaces. At −0.2 and −0.5 V, the Pt-Pd-Te-NWs/CF exhibited MA values of 0.76 and 1.48 A mg−1 Pt, which were 4 and 4.48 times higher than those of the carbon-supported Pt catalyst (0.19 and 0.33 A mg−1 Pt), respectively. Furthermore, in the low-potential area, the PtPdTe-NWs/CF showed more MA compared with those for G-PtPd (0.115 A mg−1 Pt) [174], NP-Pt20Pd80 (0.22 A mg−1 Pt), NP-Pt75Pd25 (0.25 A mg−1 Pt) [175], and Pt3Pd NRs (0.115 A mg−1 Pt) [176]. It was concluded that the obtained ternary 1D nanowires demonstrated excellent ORR catalytic ability in alkaline environments owing to their exceptional porous constructions along with synergetic effects between three metallic species. Notably, the increased affinity of oxygen toward Pd positions resulted in intensified connections between oxygen and the Pt-Pd-Te alloyed sample. This intensified interaction can facilitate the disruption of OO bonds, eventually conferring a noticeable improvement in oxygen reduction activities. Kong et al. [177] designed the carbon-supported PtPdNi octahedral nanocages (NCs) for oxygen reduction by adding Ni metals to the PtPd system. As confirmed by the X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS) analysis, the Pt3PdNi octahedral NCs showed improved ORR performance over their single and binary analogs because of a tailored geometric and electronic configuration by the inclusion of Ni elements. The carbon-supported Pt3PdNi NCs outperformed Pt3Pd NCs and commercial Pt/C for oxygen reduction in acidic electrolytes, with the MA of 1.17 A mg−1 Pt and the SA of 3.8 mA cm−2. DFT studies and XAFS measurements suggested that the ligand and compressive strain effects could result in increased ORR performance by lowering the adsorption of oxygenated species on the catalyst surface. As a result of high vacancy formation energy and architectural stability, the ternary Pt3PdNi NCs exhibited outstanding long-term durability, with 16 % performance losses after consecutive CV cycling. Thus, the authors concluded that octahedral Pt3PdNi NCs represent a novel category of catalysts for oxygen reduction. A simple synthesis of ternary Pd-Pt-Fe nanoalloys by utilizing the spray dehydration-annealing strategy (Fig. 11 a) was reported by Zhu et al. [103]. They determined that controlling the composition and altering the structures could effectively promote the electro-activities of Pd-Pt-Fe/C alloyed nanocatalysts toward ORR. TEM analyses of Pd0.75Pt0.25Fe/C revealed that spherical nanoparticles with a narrow distribution were evenly scattered over the supporting material surface (Fig. 11b and c). The HAADF-STEM and EDX mapping images of the Pd0.75Pt0.25Fe/C nanocatalyst confirmed the existence of Fe, Pd, and Pt elements in the ternary sample (Fig. 11d and e). Interestingly, the polarization plots of PdPtFe/C catalysts were situated to the right of those belonging to the PdFe/C alloyed nanocatalyst. This observation proved a substantial improvement in oxygen reduction kinetics for ternary alloyed samples (Fig. 11g). The E1/2 demonstrated a pattern resembling a "volcano curve" as the quantity of Pt was increased, following this sequence: PdFe/C < Pd0.9Pt0.1Fe/C < Pd0.5Pt0.5Fe/C < D-Pd0.75Pt0.25Fe/C < Pd0.75Pt0.25Fe/C. As shown in Fig. 11f and g, among the investigated catalysts, the Pd0.75Pt0.25Fe/C alloy displayed the highest performance on account of the synergistic interplay between ligand and strain effects. By taking advantage of the compressive strains resulting from the relatively tight construction of the ordered configuration, the adsorption energy of the oxygenate intermediates was greatly reduced, which could contribute to superior oxygen reduction catalytic ability in acidic circumstances. As compared with the disordered Pd0.75Pt0.25Fe/C nanoalloy, the ordered one showed remarkably superior stability after 10,000 cycles in ADTs. Consequently, the strategy of fabricating ordered ternary alloyed materials in their research provides a novel perspective to optimizing nanocatalysts in fuel cell systems. Sun et al. [178] used a chemical reduction approach to prepare a set of trimetallic Pd-Ni-M (M = Sn or Cu) alloyed nanoparticles coated on nitrogen-doped graphene (NG) for catalyzing ORR. Physical evaluations of the catalysts demonstrated the formation of ternary alloys and uniform scattering of metal nanoparticles on the surface of NG. The XRD spectra of Pd-Ni/NG, Pd-Ni-Sn/NG, and Pd-Ni-Cu/NG electro-catalysts displayed no characteristic peaks corresponding to Ni, Sn, or Cu. Thus, it can be inferred that Pd alloyed structures were successfully produced on NG substrates. The electro-chemical tests revealed that the ORR activity followed the ordering NG < Pd-Ni/NG < Pd black (20 %) < Pd-Ni-Cu/NG < Pd-Ni-Sn/NG < Pt/C (20 %) in alkaline media. Their findings showed that introducing Sn or Cu as a third metal into a Pd-Ni alloyed nanocatalyst could decrease Pd quantity, thereby significantly increasing ORR catalytic activity and durability. To increase catalyst utilization and improve electro-catalytic performance, core-shell nanostructures consisting of one or two Pd sheets over metallic alloy surfaces have attracted considerable interest. Furthermore, conventional Pt-alloyed nanocatalysts demonstrate limited longevity due to the tendency of alloying transition metals to dissolve readily in the electrolytes during cathodic operation conditions. In addressing this issue, alloy formation between Pt-based materials and other precious metals like Pd is identified as an efficient strategy for enhancing catalyst stability. In a recent study, Park et al. [179] illustrated a simple preparation of carbon-supported PdM@Pt (M = Mn and Fe) core-shell nanoparticles (NPs) with differential metal contents (Pd49Fe21@Pt30, Pd46Mn6@Pt48, Pd17Fe31@Pt52, and Pd15Mn5@Pt80) through an ultrasound-assisted polyol synthesis technique. It turned out that these carbon-supported PdM@Pt materials achieved improved ORR catalytic performance relative to Pt/C. This improvement may be related to the modification of the Pt electronic arrangement as well as the dilution impact resulting from the construction of core-shell nanostructures. Recently, Cruz-Martı´nez et al. [180] explored the construction of carbon-supported Ni-Pd-Pt nanoparticles using an oleylamine-oleic acid mixture for catalyzing ORR. EDX and XRD analyses verified the existence of Ni, Pt, and Pd metallic constituents in the catalyst. Both EDX and SEM measurements confirmed that the atomic proportion of Ni/Pd/Pt in this nanocatalyst was 55.9: 19.4: 24.7, which agreed well with the nominal atomic ratio. The electro-chemical results indicated that the Ni-Pd-Pt/C sample had a larger ECSA (80.78 m2/g Pt) compared to the Pt/C catalyst (58.70 m2/g Pt). In acidic environments, ternary Ni-Pd-Pt/C catalysts possessed superior MA and SA (202.3 mA mg−1 Pt and 250.8 µA cm−2 Pt) toward oxygen reduction compared with the carbon-supported Pt catalyst (121.2 mA mg−1 Pt and 206.4 µA cm−2 Pt). In addition, the prepared ternary sample indicated optimistic long-term durability. The enhanced ORR catalytic capability and durability of ternary Ni-Pd-Pt materials can be linked to the collaborative interplay between Ni and other metallic components. Hence, the Ni-Pd-Pt/C catalyst has the potential to be a favorable choice for fuel cell cathode electrodes. In another study conducted by Tinoco-Munoz et al. [181], they fabricated binary Ni-Pd and ternary Ni-Pd-Pt electro-catalysts supported on carbon with low Pt contents to investigate the impact of incorporating other non-noble metals on oxygen reduction performance. The XRD analysis proved the existence of both binary Ni-Pd and ternary Ni-Pd-Pt catalysts, with a minor shifting of the diffraction peak position toward higher angles in the Ni-Pd sample. This showed a potential lattice contraction influence of Pd, possibly due to its effort to conform to the lattice of Ni. Because of the integration of Pt into the Ni-Pd alloyed system, an additional peak emerged at 26.2° in the carbon-supported (Ni80Pd20) Pt20 material, indicating the construction of a different phase. EDX images of the carbon-supported (Ni80Pd20) Pt20 material revealed a higher quantity of Pt at the edges of the ternary catalyst, which suggested the formation of a core-shell nanostructure through the wrapping of binary Ni-Pd systems with Pt. It was found that MA (84.7 mA/mg) and SA (47.6 mA/cm2) values of the ternary (Ni80Pd20) Pt20/C sample were about 3 and 2.5 times higher than those of the binary Ni80Pd20/C catalyst in acidic conditions. These improved activities may be attributed to the effective utilization of Pt resulting from structural and electronic modifications induced by the presence of third metallic elements. Other supported ternary nanomaterials, including Mn-Fe-Ni/MWCNT [182], Fe-Co-Ni/MWCNT [183], nitrogen-doped Pt-Ni-Mo/C [184], and Cu-Pt-Pd/C [26] are also impressive ORR nanocatalysts. The performances of some ternary catalysts with different supporting materials are listed in Table 2 . Based on the discussion above, it is evident that the existence of three metallic components can modify the electronic structure of catalysts, thereby promoting ORR. Compared to their single and binary analogs, ternary catalysts exhibit improved ORR behaviors by capitalizing on synergistic active centers, optimized electronic and geometric properties, combining individual strengths, enhanced mass transport, improved stability, and decreased degradation over time, as summarized in Fig. 12 . Apart from these benefits, no precise mechanism exists to specify each metallic component's role. As a result, further investigation is required into the connection between their ORR catalytic mechanisms and construction to develop desirable ternary catalysts. 5 Application of ternary nanomaterials as cathode catalysts in fuel cells The development of more economical metallic nanocatalysts with excellent catalytic ability and high durability in real fuel cell environments is a formidable challenge faced by investigators. Evidently, with the introduction of binary alloys, catalyst engineering has been driven toward enhancing the inherent electro-catalytic activity instead of long-term durability. As a result, the RDE experiment has been extensively used as a standard technique to unravel the electro-catalytic properties of catalysts toward oxygen reduction. Nevertheless, real operational conditions necessitate experiments in a complete cell setup with a membrane electrode assembly (MEA). In most cases, the high capabilities of nanostructured materials achieved in half-cell tests cannot be translated into the same effectiveness in MEAs. The RDE testing environments, which include liquid solutions, low currents, thin film nanocatalyst layers, and rotation-induced solution flow to the RDE, are vital in minimizing the adverse impact of mass transport and resistance losses on fuel cell efficiency during practical operation [205–207]. Therefore, the performance of recently developed oxygen reduction nanocatalysts is not confidently estimated using RDE analyses of half-cells. Indeed, there have been significant advancements in measurement techniques, like the floating electrode technique (FET) and the gas diffusion electrode (GDE), which have been specifically designed to enhance mass transfer in RDE setups [208–211]. This leads to a stronger emphasis on durability enhancement explorations and expedites the usage of laboratory-level nanocatalysts for MEAs. Below are some recent explorations of ternary nanostructured cathodes for proton exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs) and direct methanol fuel cells (DMFCs). 5.1 Proton exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs) PEMFCs are commonly utilized in automobiles and portable devices due to their quick start-up, high energy efficiency, and low working temperature. Nonetheless, essential parts of PEMFCs, such as catalysts, membranes, and electrodes, are still undergoing extensive development to address substantial challenges related to costs, activity, and stability. Increasing the stability and affordability of PEMFCs is essential for their widespread industrial applications. This is partly attributed to the expensive Pt electro-catalysts, which constitute a substantial portion of the overall production expenses of PEMFC systems [212]. Presently, alloyed nanomaterials are regarded as a feasible option for reducing the cost of PEMFCs and decreasing the Pt content in the electro-catalyst [89,206,213,214]. Binary cathodic catalysts such as PtCu, PdSn, and PdPt have demonstrated exceptional performances in fuel cells [33,215,216]. Despite the promising results achieved with binary catalysts, their performance is still low under fuel cell operating conditions. Moreover, long-term durability remains a substantial obstacle. While attempts to overcome binary catalyst limitations through compositional and structural modifications have encountered difficulties, the incorporation of a third metallic component into binary catalysts has emerged as a compelling alternative approach. However, ternary catalysts' progress is often hindered by their intricate structure, which encompasses various combinations and interconnected interplays of elements. The recent investigations of ternary catalysts, which are described below, demonstrate that the inclusion of third metallic elements into binary systems can improve the durability of nanocatalysts for catalyzing oxygen reduction. These trimetallic catalysts also display high electro-catalytic capability. The reason for this is their optimal surface strength, which enables the easy absorption and desorption of oxygenated intermediates. Numerous efforts have been undertaken to elucidate the functions of third metallic components in ternary nanomaterials, specifically their contribution to enhancing electro-catalyst durability. As an example, Mohanraju et al. [101] demonstrated the fabrication of ternary Pt-Fe-Co/C and Pd-Fe-Co/C alloy nanocatalysts through a solvothermal technique. The prepared ternary alloy catalysts and single metallic samples confirmed the fcc structure. Ternary catalysts displayed quite similar diffraction peaks to those of their respective pure analogs, with a slight shift toward greater 2θ values. Based on TEM analyses, Pd-Fe-Co/C and Pt-Fe-Co/C alloys had particle sizes of ca. 7.5 and 4 nm, respectively. The authors found that both Pd-Fe-Co and Pt-Fe-Co nanocatalysts possessed different lattice constants from their single Pd and Pt metallic counterparts, probably due to alloy formation. The compressive strain value of Pd-Fe-Co/C was higher than that of the Pt-Fe-Co/C alloy catalyst. The CV characterization confirmed that the Pd-Fe-Co/C sample exhibited a significant increase in oxide reduction potential compared with Pt-Fe-Co/C. The electro-chemical results suggested that the ternary alloy materials followed the 1e− transfer rate-controlling step as well as a 4e− ORR pathway. The values of MA and SA of Pd-Fe-Co/C presented greater augmentations than those of the Pt-Fe-Co/C sample relative to the Pd/C and Pt/C monometallic catalysts. The performance of fuel cells assembled with Pd-Fe-Co/C and Pt-Fe-Co/C cathode catalysts was examined at 60, 70, and 80 °C. At 80 °C, the Pd-Fe-Co/C and Pt-Fe-Co/C alloys had peak power densities of 437 and 713 mW/cm2, respectively. It turned out that both ternary samples had better fuel cell performances than single metal cathodes due to their lattice strain. In accordance with the Pt-Fe-Co/C lattice constants, pure Pt metallic catalyst showed a higher density than Pd, resulting in lower compressive strain and contraction upon alloy generation. In 2016, the same team [217] also described an efficient and facile approach to the preparation of ternary Pt-M-Co/C (M = Ni, Cr, Fe, Mn, and Cu) alloyed catalysts with an atomic ratio of 6:3:1 for ORR in PEMFCs. TEM analyses revealed that well-distributed ternary nanoparticles (ranging between 2.1 and 3.0 nm) were formed on carbon substrates. XRD plots of ternary Pt-M-Co/C alloy samples demonstrated the fcc structures with crystallite sizes varying from 2.0 to 2.5 nm. Among all the proposed samples, the Pt-Fe-Co/C nanocatalyst possessed the largest ECSA (156.2 m2/g) as well as the highest improvement in oxygen reduction activity and stability. Compared with the other ternary alloy catalysts, Pt-Fe-Co/C had the highest E1/2 of 0.760 V, and this value was around 45 and 57 mV greater than that of binary Pt-Co/C and commercial Pt/C, respectively. In addition, the ternary Pt-M-Co/C catalysts showed better performances than commercial Pt/C under actual working conditions of H2/O2 PEMFCs. Interestingly, Pt-Fe-Co/C recorded a superior power density (841 mW/cm2) than that of the carbon-supported Pt catalyst (666 mW/cm2). The obtained results indicated that the formed alloy structures between Pt and first-row transition metal elements could improve fuel cell effectiveness owing to the larger surface area of the resulting ternary catalysts. It is imperative to inhibit metallic elements from dissolving while preserving their boosting impact on oxygen reduction ability to make nanocatalysts with striking catalytic properties and electro-chemical stability for real-world PEMFC use of MEAs. The material project database demonstrates that L10-PtMn has a comparatively negative alloy formation energy, which increases nanocatalyst durability. Recently, Qin et al. [218] introduced ternary intermetallic L10-PtCoMn alloyed samples and explored the influence of elemental composition on oxygen reduction catalysis in PEMFCs. Among the binary and ternary alloy materials investigated, L10-PtCo0.8Mn0.2 displayed the highest electro-catalytic ability and durability in the half-cell experiments. As seen in Fig. 13 a and b, the L10-PtCo0.8Mn0.2 nanocatalyst revealed excellent performance in PEMFCs, achieving the MA of 0.954 A mg−1 Pt with just around 8.6 % degradation after 30,000 ADT cycles, exceeding the activity and stability benchmarks set by the Department of Energy (DOE). Supported by experimental evaluations and DFT studies, a volcanic-type trend in adsorption energy (ΔEO*) and reaction ability has been derived (Fig. 13c), representing that the optimum ternary sample showed suitable adsorption, thus enhancing oxygen reduction performances. DFT analyses have also verified that the superior durability of the optimum catalyst comes from the addition of Mn, which enhances the alloy's formation energy (Fig. 13d), stabilizes its construction (Fig. 13e), and augments bonding and atomic connections within the alloyed structure. The copper (Cu) element has abundant reserves and excellent electro-chemical stability. It offers comparable improvements in oxygen reduction due to lattice strain effects when alloyed with Pt. A very recent study by Hu et al. [219] reported a simple co-doping approach to construct ternary PtCoCu alloyed catalysts with impressive ORR catalytic ability and stability in PEMFCs. It was stated that PtCu0.72Co0.01 indicated the highest E1/2 (0.915 V) compared with that for PtCo0.016 (0.894 V), PtCu0.72 (0.907 V), and carbon-supported Pt (0.888 V) catalysts. More importantly, the obtained PtCu0.72Co0.01 sample outperformed Pt/C catalyst toward oxygen reduction under acidic conditions, with the MA of 0.52 A/mg Pt and the SA of 1.34 mA/cm2 Pt. Furthermore, after ADTs, the PtCu0.72Co0.01 catalyst notably showed a high ORR durability with just 8.3 % performance loss compared to PtCo0.016 (60 %), PtCu0.72 (34 %), and carbon-supported Pt (69 %) catalysts. The PtCu0.72Co0.01 alloyed catalyst led to maximum power densities of 1.15 and 1.63 W/cm2 in H2-Air and H2 O2 PEMFCs, respectively, with a 4.2 % decline in current density after fuel cell continuous operation for 44 h at a fixed voltage of 0.6 V as compared with the Pt/C catalyst. This exhibited clear superiority over binary samples and Pt/C regarding cathodic capability, suggesting promising possibilities for practical applications. The robust compressive strain originating from the addition of Co and Cu to the Pt lattice contributed to this unprecedented performance. Wang et al. [220] proposed a facile and effective impregnation reduction method to fabricate ternary PtCuxNi1-x/C nanocatalysts for ORR in PEMFCs. According to TEM images, PtCu0.5Ni0.5/C-700 nanoparticles with an average size of 5.18 nm were consistently dispersed over the substrate surface. The XPS examination revealed that following high-temperature calcination in the H2 atmosphere, a fraction of Pt atoms within the nanoparticles relocated to the surface. Consequently, Pt-enriched layers appeared on the surface of catalysts. The strain effects between the surface Pt layer and alloying metals (Ni and Cu) within the ternary alloyed structure can diminish Pt affinity for competing oxygenated species by lowering the Pt electron cloud densities, enhancing oxygen reduction abilities. The electro-chemical findings revealed that the E1/2 values for the prepared nanocatalysts followed the order of Pt/C < Pt-Cu/C-700 < PtCu0.75Ni0.25/C-700 < PtCu0.5Ni0.5/C-700. It was determined that the ternary Pt-Cu-Ni/C material showed better ORR catalytic performance than binary Pt-Cu/C and Pt-Ni/C samples. The PtCu0.5Ni0.5/C-700 showed superior ORR capability with a 9.2-fold higher MA (ca. 1.3 A/mg Pt at 0.9 V vs. RHE) compared to commercial carbon-supported Pt catalysts. The authors found that the PtCu0.5Ni0.5/C-700 nanocatalyst recorded a power density of 461 mW/cm2 and a current density of 968 mA/cm2, which were higher than those for Pt-Cu/C (390 mW/cm2 and 909 mA/cm2) and Pt/C (359 mW/cm2 and 945 mA/cm2).
