It turned out that the integration of the Ni element in a binary Pt-Cu/C sample could alter Pt's electronic configuration, increasing oxygen binding energies toward oxygen reduction. This research indicates that the ternary PtCu0.5Ni0.5/C-700 sample can function as a remarkably effective and long-lasting nanocatalyst for oxygen reduction in fuel cell technologies. In another related work, Fang et al. [221] described the catalytic performance of ternary Pt-Ni-Fe/C nanocatalysts in PEMFCs. The MEAs were fabricated with Pt-Ni-Fe/C samples, heat-treated at 400 and 800 °C, as cathodic nanocatalysts. The ICP-OES analysis showed that the Pt:Ni:Fe composition of the resulting ternary catalyst was 46:22:32. The mass activities of Pt46Ni22Fe32/C at 400 and 800 °C were 0.38 and 0.27 A/mg Pt, respectively, both greater than that of Pt/C (0.22 A/mg Pt), highlighting the enhanced ORR catalytic ability of the ternary sample. They also observed that carbon-supported Pt-Ni-Fe cathode nanocatalysts outperformed carbon-supported Pt catalysts in PEMFCs. Moreover, the heat-treatment process of the ternary electro-catalysts affected both catalytic and fuel cell performances. Compared to the lower-temperature treated catalyst (0.62 W/cm2) and Pt/C (0.52 W/cm2), the higher-temperature treated ones displayed better PEMFC power output (1.21 W/cm2) due to considerably more alloy formation. The authors suggested that the improvement in catalytic performance could be related to the lattice-shrinking influence, which has also been evident in other alloy nanocatalysts [222,223]. In fact, the majority of oxygen reduction nanocatalysts demonstrated unsatisfactory efficiency in practical PEMFCs. The high activity obtained in half-cells was severely suppressed under the harsh operating environments of actual fuel cell devices because of the noticeably increased oxygen diffusion tolerance, the severe accumulation of nanoparticles, and the poor durability of nanostructured catalysts. In ORR electro-catalysis, highly active materials often exhibit limited durability owing to nanostructure deterioration during the reaction procedure. Hence, high durability is generally dependent on sacrificed activity [224]. Another serious issue that drastically impairs the effectiveness and durability of fuel cell systems is the oxidation and dissolution of metallic catalysts [225,226]. It is vital to implement organized assessments of diverse electro-catalysts in actual PEMFCs rather than focusing on achieving high activities as measured by half-cell experiments. Even with these challenges, considerable advancements have been observed in devising and manufacturing multicomponent nanomaterials in the last few years [171,227,228]. Most of these materials still suffer significant stagnation in half-cells when translated into PEMFCs. Therefore, more profound research on the development of ternary electro-catalysts under real fuel cell operational environments is critical to designing inexpensive, effective, and reliable nanocatalysts for the widespread adoption of PEMFCs. 5.2 Direct methanol fuel cells (DMFCs) Direct methanol fuel cells (DMFCs) have been postulated as a prospective technology for a vast array of energy-demanding applications owing to their high proficiency, environmental friendliness, and operational simplicity [229–234]. Moreover, liquid methanol, which is convenient for transportation and storage, possesses a high theoretical energy density [7,8,166,235–237]. Nevertheless, one of the notable barriers to industrial applications of DMFC systems is the cross-over of methanol through the membranes, which causes a mixed potential at the cathode and decreases fuel cell efficiency [6,15,238,239]. In this context, innovative cathodic nanocatalysts with superior oxygen reduction activity and methanol resistance are being developed [240,241]. Ternary nanocatalysts seem to meet these needs and have consequently been examined in DMFC devices. Several studies have concentrated on designing nanocatalysts that cannot absorb methanol while still presenting excellent ORR capabilities in DMFCs. In this sense, Escudero-Cid et al. [242] explored the long-term durability of carbon-supported Pt-Co-Ru catalysts with respect to the cross-over of methanol (MeOH) in DMFC systems. The degradation of DMFCs assembled with both Pt-Co-Ru/C and Pt/C cathodic electro-catalysts, along with commercial Pt-Ru/C anodic electro-catalysts, was investigated by evaluating the decline in power density. After 312 h of continuous operation, the DMFC with a Pt-Co-Ru/C cathodic electrode showed superior performance to that of a carbon-supported Pt catalyst, consistent with LSV investigations. The authors proposed that the strong tolerance of the ternary Pt-Co-Ru/C nanocatalyst toward MeOH cross-over on the cathodic side was the primary reason for the remarkable ORR activity and durability. The increased MeOH tolerance of this sample can be attributed to the existence of stable upper oxide species of Ru, which persist under oxygen-saturated conditions at elevated potentials. The presence of such species prevents MeOH from attaching to Pt active positions, thus keeping them accessible for adsorption and subsequent reduction of oxygen. In order to determine the critical degradation mechanisms related to the performance loss of the employed DMFC, electro-chemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) analyses were carried out in their study. It was claimed that the extent of degradation was associated with an increase in anode resistance. Over consecutive voltage cycling (312 h), the oxygen reduction resistance decreased. This apparent inconsistency could be due to the alteration of the cathodic material into a more highly reactive oxygen reduction nanocatalyst with lower tolerance to the cross-over of MeOH. To achieve satisfactory performance of Pt alloy samples for oxygen reduction in real DMFCs, Wang et al. [145] utilized a sequential galvanic displacement procedure to synthesize ternary Pt-Au-Cu/C nanocatalysts with diverse metallic proportions. Upon electro-chemical dealloying, a rich Pt-Au surface was revealed over the Pt-Au-Cu catalysts. The trimetallic sample displayed higher oxygen reduction abilities compared to both Pt10Cu36 and Pt/C catalysts. According to their results, the Pt10Au10Cu64 catalyst possessed a high positive E1/2 together with SA and MA of about 0.45 mA/cm2 and 0.38 A/mg Pt, which were nearly 1.4 and 1.7 times more than those for the Pt10Cu36 catalyst (0.32 mA/cm2 and 0.22 A/mg Pt) and 1.8 and 2.2 times greater than those for the carbon-supported Pt catalyst (0.25 mA/cm2 and 0.17 A/mg Pt). Moreover, the Pt10Au10Cu64 catalyst displayed the highest methanol resistance and durability toward oxygen reduction. After ADT tests, the SA and MA of Pt/C dropped by approximately 38.61 % and 48.82 %, respectively, representing a significantly higher decline than those observed in Pt10Au10Cu64. The improved electro-chemical activity of the trimetallic catalyst can be attributed to its electronic, geometric, and surface structure properties. The addition of Cu and Au into the lattice of Pt can induce compressive strain, change the electronic configuration, lower the d-band position of Pt, and reduce the binding strength of oxygen intermediates to Pt, eventually improving ORR performance. Recent research studies have explored Pd-containing alloy nanomaterials as cathodic catalysts due to their excellent oxygen reduction performance and methanol resistance [243–247]. Specifically, Pd-Co alloys have been investigated as methanol-tolerant cathodic materials for DMFC systems. Remarkably, Pd-Co nanocatalysts display superior oxygen reduction abilities in the presence of methanol because Pd is less active in methanol oxidation compared with Pt/C [243]. However, metal dissolution has been a significant issue for bimetallic Pd alloys. One possible method to avoid metal dissolution and enhance nanocatalyst durability is the preparation of multimetallic Pd nanomaterials. For example, Lee et al. [248] fabricated ternary Pd alloyed catalysts supported on carbon with a reduction technique using NaBH4. The EDX results verified the presence of Ni and Co constituents in the prepared samples. The atomic proportions of Pd:Co:Ni in the Pd7Co1Ni2/C, Pd7Co2Ni1/C, and Pd7Co3/C materials, which closely matched the intended values, were 69:10:21, 69:20:11, and 68:32:0, respectively. The carbon-supported Pd7Co2Ni1 material manifested some advantageous attributes, including excellent methanol resistance capacity, high current density (−2.53 mA/cm2), and high MA (3162.6 mA/g Pd), surpassing both Pd7Co3/C (−2.11 mA/cm2 and 2637.5 mA/g Pd) and Pd/C (−1.85 mA/cm2 and 1618.8 mA/g Pd) catalysts. Because of the enhanced methanol resistance revealed by the Pd7Co2Ni1 and Pd7Co3/C nanocatalysts, the open circuit voltage (OCV) of MEAs with Pd7Co2Ni1 (0.64 V) and Pd7Co3/C (0.64 V) exceeded that of Pt/C (0.62 V) in actual DMFC systems. In addition, the optimum ternary catalyst displayed striking cathodic performance (power density of 49 mW/cm2) in a real DMFC. It was concluded that the incorporation of Ni and Co into Pd resulted in promoted ORR catalytic properties and methanol tolerance in the ternary Pd-based sample. Cho et al. [249] applied a sodium borohydride method to make ternary Pt-Pd-Co/C catalysts for DMFC cathode electrodes. The HRTEM technique showed that nanoscale Pt-Pd-Co particles with average sizes of about 2.4 nm were evenly scattered over the carbon-supporting material surfaces (Fig. 14 a–c). The OCV of the MEA with Pt-Pd-Co/C (0.81 V) in 0.5 M MeOH was higher than that for Pt-Pd/C (0.79 V) and Pt/C (0.75 V). The obtained ternary nanocatalysts displayed oxygen reduction abilities comparable to those of carbon-supported Pt catalysts, along with increased methanol resistance in half-cell studies and full-cell evaluations (Fig. 14d and e). After continuous operation for 1000 h, the ternary catalyst performance diminished by around 14 %, whereas the Pt/C power density dropped by almost 30 % under identical test conditions (Fig. 14f). It was suggested that the displacement of the d-band positions could arise from strain influence caused by the lattice mismatch in trimetallic Pt-Pd-Co catalysts, weakening the adsorption strength of surface oxygenated species and therefore enhancing ORR catalytic properties. In another investigation, Rivera-Gavidia et al. [250] analyzed the impact of various MeOH concentrations on the oxygen reduction performance of a series of carbon-supported Pd catalysts. They used some techniques to examine the results of oxygen reduction catalysis in the presence or absence of MeOH. Their findings demonstrated that a ternary Pd-Fe-Ir/C sample had higher ORR capability than binary Pd-Ir/C, Pd-Fe/C analogs, and Pd/C in the absence and presence of MeOH. The authors also found that incorporating Ir and Fe components could inhibit Pd oxide production, thereby increasing MeOH resistance. Consequently, the synthesized ternary Pd-Fe-Ir/C nanomaterial emerged as a suitable cathode electro-catalyst for practical DMFCs. Their research represents a breakthrough in replacing expensive and unreliable materials using ternary nanostructured catalysts by translating their results into practical reality. It also provides opportunities for oxygen reduction electro-catalysis to be more cost-effective and long-lasting in DMFC applications. To sum up, the studied ternary nanocatalysts demonstrated prominent ORR electro-catalytic capabilities and methanol resistance. Ternary catalysts are designed to address the methanol cross-over issue by incorporating three diverse kinds of active positions or metals that act synergistically to boost catalytic selectivity and ORR performance. Pt-containing catalysts are among the most extensively investigated ternary nanomaterials due to their effectiveness in oxygen reduction catalysis. A reasonable option that could help mitigate the limitations of employing Pt material solely as a catalyst would be the incorporation of tiny quantities of Pt into specific binary nanocatalysts. In addition, other ternary catalysts have shown striking catalytic activity for oxygen reduction in DMFCs. The existence of third elements restrains the generation of oxygenated species, promoting the methanol resistance of ternary samples. Ternary nanocatalysts overcome methanol cross-over through improved selectivity, synergistic interactions, and tolerance to poisoning. The specific mechanisms depend on the ternary catalyst composition and the reaction environment. Researchers often combine computational modeling and experimental methods to elucidate these mechanisms and fabricate more effective ORR nanomaterials. However, further research is still necessary not only to thoroughly understand the ORR catalytic mechanisms of these ternary nanocatalysts but also to identify the crucial relationships between inherent material attributes, durability, and DMFC operational conditions. 6 Strategies for the optimal design of ternary ORR catalysts The exploration of ternary catalysts discussed earlier shows that incorporating additional third metallic elements into such nanomaterials has a notable impact on their stabilization. Moreover, the specific functions of these third components are being revealed, specifically in terms of enhancing catalyst durability. Irrespective of the kind of ternary catalysts, most investigations specify that catalytically reactive points are ultimately generated in electro-catalysis or fabrication procedures. In this context, the third metallic element plays a pivotal role in stabilizing electro-catalytic points and highly sensitive areas of catalysts, contingent on their types and regional dispersion. In this part of the review, the advantageous influences and regional dispersion of third metallic components within ternary catalysts have been concisely described. This affords valuable guidance for designing remarkably effective and durable catalysts. One of the most straightforward methods to enhance binary catalyst durability involves the introduction of a third metal that can make robust chemical bonds with other metals. Particularly, blending Au atoms with binary Pt-Cu alloys enhances their stability. This enhancement may reflect the significant electronic interactions between the Au and Cu elements. The introduction of dopants like Au and Mo into the catalyst's subsurface region can lead to strong connections with Pt and other noble metal components, effectively inhibiting subsequent dissolution processes [251,252]. In Pd-Fe alloyed systems, the electronic interactions of Cu with Pd and Fe account for the improved stability of the ternary Pd-Fe-Cu/C catalyst [171]. Another efficient strategy for maintaining Pt-free catalysts is increasing lattice diffusion barriers. Leaching happens throughout the oxygen reduction, wherein elements prone to being leached from the electro-catalysts diffuse outside via vacant positions generated in the vicinity of the surfaces. The diffusion of these elements into vacant positions is significantly impeded by an increase in energy barriers. It has been reported that the combination of In with Pt-Ni catalysts can raise the lattice atom diffusion energy barriers against Ni diffusion into vacant positions and lower particle surface energy, enhancing stability by slowing down the leaching of Ni and protecting the reactive layers [157]. As the oxygen reduction procedures include the oxidation of noble metal catalysts, the electropositive elements can cause electronic influences that prevent noble metals from oxidizing and dissolving. Au's electron-donating nature increases the oxidation potential of adjacent noble metal elements. The dissolution of noble metals is efficiently restricted in the oxygen reduction process by the inclination of weak oxophilicity along with outward phase segregation of Au [119]. For example, Au integration into the Pt-Cu catalyst could stabilize the surface and inhibit Pt oxidization [125]. Moreover, Pt-enriched layers are generated spontaneously in oxygen reduction procedures, and these zones are remarkably durable. Nevertheless, the catalyst's uppermost layers inevitably possess defective positions and grains. Therefore, Pt and other noble metal elements dissolve within these low-coordinated points. Some computational and empirical investigations have shown the blocking influence of Au and Mo elements [125,203]. For instance, the low surface energy of Au leads to outward phase segregation, resulting in selective Au accumulation in low-coordinated points. This process efficiently hinders the dissolution of susceptible interior elements. Rational engineering of effective and durable multicomponent catalysts is enabled by approaches developed for ternary materials. It is essential to put the third metallic constituent in a location where it can reach its maximal potential for stabilizing nanocatalysts without obstructing oxygen reduction procedures. It is preferable to design the interior of catalysts in a Pt-free or low Pt proportion to lower fabrication prices. This is because the interior is somewhat distant from the electro-catalytic surface and has a limited impact on the catalyst's properties. However, the phase needs to be electro-chemically durable to avoid dissolution. Considering this aspect, the selection of third metallic components must prioritize their ability to interact strongly with Pt and other noble metal elements or induce a greater lattice diffusion barrier for decelerating transition metals from leaching into electrolytes. The third metallic constituent plays a crucial role in stabilizing electro-catalytic layers by providing powerful chemical connections and causing electronic influences in sublayers. Indeed, interior areas can also be protected by stable sublayers. In addition, surfaces can be altered through processes like alloy formation and blockage of low-coordinated positions. Specifically, the favorable segregation of the Au core into the defective areas of the PdPt shell layer minimizes the degradation of surface shell layer constituents, resulting in excellent stability of Au@PdPt pNWs [120]. Also, Pd shows an incredible ability to form alloys with Pt. The addition of Pd elements to the Pt3Ni (111) surface can prevent Pt segregation, considerably enhancing the durability of the Pt-Pd alloyed system compared to Pt alone [253]. Ultimately, the blockage of low-coordinated edge and corner positions proves to be a helpful tactic in ensuring brilliant electro-catalytic properties while also avoiding excessively energetic points where Pt and other elements might leach out into the electrolyte [254]. 7 Summary, challenges, and perspectives Over the past decades, metallic nanoparticles have been extensively explored as excellent ORR catalysts. Nanoparticles have been developed in diverse morphological structures by adding other elements to boost their catalytic abilities. The present review deliberates the design of a variety of support-free and supported ternary nanostructured catalysts for ORR. Because of the plausible synergistic effects of three metallic constituents, ternary nanocatalysts possess exceptionally desirable characteristics and striking ORR catalytic capabilities in PEMFC and DMFC systems. The various morphological features (such as nanowires, nanodendrites, nanoflowers, nanocrystals, and nanocubes) and compositions (such as core-shell, alloy, and intermetallic) of ternary catalysts, which need to be monitored through preparation conditions, have a favorable impact on the ORR performance of these nanomaterials. In comparison to single and binary electro-catalysts, ternary nanomaterials have demonstrated improved ORR activity, durability, and methanol resistance. Despite the tremendous advancements described in the preceding sections, some challenges and opportunities remain in the development of ternary nanostructured materials as cathodic catalysts for fuel cell systems, and more efforts must be given to the following aspects in the future: (1) It is challenging to determine the atomic fraction of metallic elements using chemical procedures owing to the complexities of reduction mechanisms of metal predecessors. Indeed, the commercialization of ternary nanomaterials is restricted by the absence of continuous, repeatable, and scalable preparation methods. Current ternary nanocatalyst production techniques usually consist of multiple stages, which are cumbersome and expensive, leading to substantial starting material losses along with improper product management. These techniques do not produce the desired morphological nanostructures and ORR electro-catalytic activities. Thus, developing straightforward, efficient, and controllable fabrication procedures is vital. (2) There are difficulties in identifying the dominant synergistic effects of trimetallic nanostructures. Synergistic effects are well known to be the most desirable consequences of electro-catalyst fabrication and catalytic activity. By combining various modification techniques, remarkable improvements can be achieved. Nevertheless, randomly combining various modification techniques may not necessarily result in synergistic enhancements, and it may even decrease electro-catalytic capabilities. In this regard, significant efforts are required to fabricate advanced ternary nanocatalysts with favorable compositions, morphologies, and particle sizes. These catalysts should also possess adjusted atomic distances, uniform active positions, and robust electronic interplays to increase ORR effectiveness. Optimized compositional nanostructures and morphological features, along with other properties, induce a change in the d-band position and adsorption strength of oxygenated species, ultimately improving ORR ability. A vast amount of work must be devoted to amending ternary nanocatalysts, which can provide excellent ORR activity and durability owing to the strain, ligand, interfacial, and electronic adjustments to the surfaces of these materials. However, the main issue is gaining more in-depth knowledge and efficiently implementing synergies through theoretical studies reported in the literature. Consequently, it is crucial to conduct thorough theoretical investigations of synergistic influences to identify the ideal methods for modification techniques. (3) It is still difficult to control the interfacial sites and surfaces of ternary nanomaterials to make ORR catalysts with outstanding catalytic properties. It is worth noting that poorly designed surfaces often cause degradation, along with ternary nanomaterials' low durability. Even though this seems challenging, it deserves to be investigated in more depth. The use of proper supports such as carbon nanotubes, graphene, and nitrogen-doped carbon nanomaterials with unique electro-catalytic attributes can promote the oxygen reduction ability of ternary nanocatalysts. The existence of defects may serve as stabilizing positions on the surface of substrates. The firm connection between individual metallic elements and defective sites can effectively assist in anchoring the metallic elements [171,178,255,256]. Accordingly, the increased number of reactive positions and large surface areas of ternary nanostructures must be considered in upcoming explorations since these aspects may contribute to ORR electro-catalytic activities. Hence, further research is needed to find the most efficient ternary catalysts, with an emphasis on optimizing various defective sites on substrates. (4) In spite of tremendous advancements in oxygen reduction catalysis in the past decade, challenges related to a substantial gap between RDE and MEA methods cause significant discrepancies in the assessment of nanocatalyst capabilities. This gap stems primarily from differences in catalyst layer loadings, mass transport, and working conditions. In order to fill the gap and facilitate the rapid analysis of high-performance ternary ORR catalysts, it would be advantageous to implement some mediator measurement approaches, such as FET and GDE (Fig. 15 ), which operate under simple circumstances. Such adapted configurations serve as a connection between laboratory-based RDE experiments and commercial MEAs. In addition to improving evaluation methods, upcoming studies should concentrate on designing highly active ternary catalysts that show not only increased inherent electro-catalytic ORR activity but also enhanced chemical durability. Therefore, it is imperative to translate the oxygen reduction performance examination of ternary nanostructured materials achieved through RDE into MEA to expedite the commercialization of these ORR catalysts. (5) There is a lack of sufficient understanding of the improvement mechanisms for several architectural strategies and surface engineering techniques related to catalyzing oxygen reduction procedures. Specifically, additional theoretical calculations are necessary for an all-around understanding of the reasons behind the exceptional catalytic capability and durability of ternary nanomaterials during the cathodic process. Advanced physical and electro-chemical techniques combined with theoretical investigations could provide further insights into ORR progress and ternary nanocatalyst characteristics. In summary, ternary materials with well-defined nanostructures and compositions strike an excellent balance between price and efficient performance in catalyzing the ORR process. So far, investigations into ternary nanostructured catalysts have concentrated on identifying catalytically active sites and improving ORR electro-catalysis. Nonetheless, it is equally critical to address the insufficient durability of these ternary catalysts under real-time working conditions. This represents a significant takeaway from the current review and should be placed on equal footing in future development. coredata.dc:description: Ternary nanostructured materials, fabricated by integrating three diverse metals, have been considered as promising cathode catalysts for fuel cells because of their synergetic effects and strain/ligand effects. That can result in effective charge transfer, weakened interactions with oxygenated species, and excellent methanol resistance. Owing to continued improvements in the production of ternary nanostructured materials, it is imperative to focus on recent advancements in this field. The present paper reviews different ternary nanostructures (i.e., support-free structures and supported catalysts), with an emphasis on their preparation methods, compositional and structural characteristics, as well as catalytic performance for oxygen reduction reactions (ORR). Moreover, the latest advances in ternary nanostructured catalysts for ORR at the cathodes of proton exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs) and direct methanol fuel cells (DMFCs) are highlighted. This work provides insights into designing advanced ternary catalysts with an analysis of challenging issues in developing highly efficient and stable nanomaterials for ORR electro-catalysis and suggests some perspectives for alleviating the difficulties toward practical implementation.
